race.tagline: Century ride featuring the Wabash Trace Trail through Silver City, Iowa.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Iowa countryside. Moderate elevation with rolling scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Local Iowa event. Rolling terrain with remote access, moderate costs, 100-mile distance, and small local field.

biased_opinion.summary: Silver City Century is a local event in Iowa—rolling terrain with moderate elevation over 100 miles. The Iowa countryside is nice and the distance is challenging, but the small local field, remote location, and limited organization keep it in Tier 4.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid local Iowa century gravel race. Worth it for Iowa/Midwest riders. Not worth traveling for.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're local to Iowa—yes, it's solid. If you're traveling—skip it.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better Iowa races: Gravel Worlds, RAGBRAI.

logistics.food: Silver City has very limited dining options. Stock nutrition.

non_negotiables.why: Limited organization and remote location require self-sufficiency.

logistics.explanation: Packet pickup the night before or morning of at the downtown gazebo with basic small-town setup. JewelerDry6222 drove an hour and wished he'd stayed for the festivities - Friday hangout and 10k run plus post-race meal and bar hang.

length.explanation: The 100km option at 62 miles with 3,600 feet provides century distance that JewelerDry6222 calls 'literally the perfect trek for a gravel grinder.' Elite rider chose the 50k with newbie friends, noting he 'didn't want to scare them off' with the full distance. Longer than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

technicality.explanation: Course features 'a lot of minimum maintenance or B roads' with terrain that's 'not too hilly, not too flat, a few surprises.' The Wabash Trace trail provides one of the course highlights for standard Midwest gravel grinding. Less technical than The Mid South.

elevation.explanation: Official description promises 'not too hilly, not too flat, a few surprises' with 3,600 feet over 62 miles. Rolling Iowa terrain that accumulates gradually rather than punishing climbs, keeping things interesting without being memorable. Less climbing than The Mid South.

climate.explanation: Riders report 'great weather with some typical Midwest wind' for recent editions. Mid-May in Iowa remains a weather gamble - could be perfect spring conditions or dealing with late-season storms and mud. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: Silver City sits well under 1,000 feet elevation with zero altitude considerations. Sea level fitness applies here with no training benefit for higher elevation events - your lungs won't notice the difference. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds — no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: Course includes the beloved Wabash Trace trail that JewelerDry6222 calls 'one of my favorite gravel trails.' Silver City is described as a community that 'loves cyclists and welcomes them everyday on the Wabash Trace.'

prestige.explanation: Part of the Iowa Gravel Series with no notable pro field or major winners mentioned. Positioned as 'the perfect opener for the season' and beginner-friendly rather than attracting serious competitive depth.

race_quality.explanation: Basic grassroots setup with chip timing, aid stations, and photos for $40-60 entry. Multi-day festivities include Friday hangout, 10k run, and post-race meal and bar hang that impressed visiting riders.

experience.explanation: Downtown Silver City start with weekend festival atmosphere including Friday evening activities and post-race celebration. Town of 250 people has a bike shop run by Mary who's described as 'amazing' by the cycling community.

community.explanation: Silver City population of 250 creates 'an amazing community that loves cyclists and welcomes them everyday.' Multi-day festivities create festival atmosphere with Friday hangout, 10k run, and post-race meal and bar hang.

field_depth.explanation: Elite rider JewelerDry6222 chose the non-competitive 50k distance with newbie friends rather than racing the century. Positioned as beginner-friendly season opener rather than attracting serious competitive racing. Thinner field than Ouray Gravel Grinder.

value.explanation: Entry fees of $40-50 grassroots or $60-70 with lunch and shirt provide decent value for century distance. Multi-day festivities with Friday activities and post-race celebration add significant value beyond the basic race entry.

expenses.explanation: Entry tops out at $70 same-day with shirt and lunch included - reasonable for century distance. Silver City, Iowa won't break the bank for lodging or dining, making this an affordable regional gravel option. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

videos.description:
There's something special about the locations where we decide to ride and race. Location is absolutely a factor in developing our love, appreciation, and talents when it comes to fitness. Just ask anyone living in Colorado... they'll remind you of the altitude benefits.

Charles Erickson grew up in Omaha, but had family in Silver City, so he knows these roads and when it came time to sign up for the Silver City Century, it was personal. He didn't want to just do well, his goal was the podium. In this episode of the podcast we get to learn a bit about how Charles balances competition and being a good guy; come to find out they both use a core skill. We also dip into nutrition and lessons learned from racing over the last decade.
